raw_text:
Peers debate Crown succession law
 
 Peers are debating proposals to change the rules governing the succession to the throne.
 
 Labour peer Lord Dubs' Succession to the Crown Bill aims to end the right of male heirs to succeed to the crown even if they have an older sister. The private member's bill would also abolish the ban on heirs to the throne marrying Roman Catholics. The Fabian Society's Sundar Katwala said the change was "long overdue" and that he expected a "warm response". The political reform group's general secretary told BBC Radio 4's Today Programme there were some "very out-dated features" at the heart of Britain's constitution.
 
 "In 1998 the government said in principle it supported the idea of ending gender discrimination and that it would consult on how to come forward with its own measures. "We hope they are warm towards it and don't say this is the wrong time." He pointed out that it was 30 years since the sex discrimination act and urged politicians on all sides to back the bill. Mr Katwala added: "This is long overdue. Parliament will have to do it eventually, the government, and I hope all of the political parties, might think this is a very simple thing to have in their manifestos."
 
 But he acknowledged that even if the bill did win support, it was unlikely to become law because the legislative programme is likely to be squeezed by the coming general election. He said he hoped the bill would be a "gentle nudge" to the government and suggested it would "demand a response". The bill, which is in the Lords for its second reading, has been adopted by former chief whip Ann Taylor in the Commons. The rule of succession is regulated not only through descent and tradition but also by the Act of Settlement which confirmed in 1701 that it was for Parliament to determine the title to the throne.
llama3.2:1b: Peers debate Crown succession law proposals.

Labour peer Lord Dubs' Succession to the Crown Bill aims to end male heirs' right to succeed to the crown if they have an older sister and abolish marriage between Roman Catholics and the throne's heirs.
The bill is part of a broader push for constitutional reform, with some arguing it is "long overdue" and others acknowledging it may not become law due to upcoming general elections.
llama3.2:3b: Peers are debating a bill to change the rules governing the British crown's succession, including ending male preference for succession and abolishing marriage bans for heirs to the throne marrying Roman Catholics.
The Fabian Society says the change is "long overdue" and expects a "warm response".
gemma2:2b: Peers are debating a bill proposed by Lord Dubs that aims to change gender-based rules governing the British monarchy's succession.
The bill seeks to end male-only inheritance and abolish bans on marriage between heirs to the throne and Roman Catholics.
The bill is supported by some who see it as long overdue, while acknowledging that its implementation might face challenges due to political priorities during the upcoming election.
qwen2.5:0.5b: In a debate over Crown succession laws, Labour peer Lord Dubs proposes changes to end gender discrimination and allow female heirs to inherit the throne.
The Fabian Society's Sundar Katwala sees the proposal as "long overdue" and expects a "warm response".
While the bill is in the Lords for second reading, it has not yet been adopted by the government or Parliament.
Lord Dubs acknowledges that even if the bill passes, it may not become law because of limited legislative power.
The bill aims to change how female heirs inherit the throne but has only been adopted by former chief whip Ann Taylor.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Peers debate changes to succession law, aiming to end gender discrimination and allow marriages to Roman Catholics; while acknowledging the bill is unlikely to pass due to upcoming general election pressure, hoping for a "gentle nudge" from lawmakers.
qwen2.5:3b: Peers debate proposals to change British succession law, including ending gender discrimination and abolishing the ban on heirs marrying Catholics.
Lord Dubs' Succession to the Crown Bill aims to implement these changes, which are seen as overdue by supporters like the Fabian Society's Sundar Katwala.
While some expect support from all parties, its legislative prospects remain uncertain due to upcoming elections, though it may prompt government action in their manifestos.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Peers are discussing a bill, Lord Dubs' Succession to the Crown Bill, proposed by Labour peer Lord Dubs.
This bill aims to eliminate the male-preference primogeniture rule, allowing sisters to inherit the throne before brothers.
It also proposes ending the ban on heirs marrying Roman Catholics.
Sundar Katwala, from the Fabian Society, advocates for this change as "long overdue," emphasizing that outdated features in Britain's constitution should be addressed.
He expects support from all political parties and urges them to include it in their manifestos, despite potential scheduling constraints due to an upcoming general election.
The bill has been adopted by Ann Taylor in the House of Commons but is still under consideration in the Lords for its second reading.
The rule of succession is currently governed by descent, tradition, and the Act of Settlement (1701), which states that Parliament decides the monarch's title.
